subject: Re: [junit] testCreate, testUpdate, testDelete: make one single test out of it?
msgSnippet: I believe you re worried that there would be a great deal of duplicate code.  Since every test in JUnit is a method, it s often times easy to convince yourself
messageBody:
I believe you're worried that there would be a great deal of duplicate
code. Since every test in JUnit is a method, it's often times easy to
convince yourself at first that every method is a test. This is not
the case. Your tests perform 5 atomic operations separate from your
tests. They are create, update, delete, exists, result. These are
regular methods; they are not tests. The tests you want are
compositions of those operations.

// Your tests

public void testCreate() {
assertFalse(exists());
create();
assertTrue(exists());
delete();
}

public void testUpdate() {
int expected = 1;
create();
assertFalse(expected == result());
update();
assertTrue(expected == result());
delete();
}

public void testDelete() {
create();
assertTrue(exists());
delete();
assertFalse(exists());
}

Not every method is a test.

-shane

On Wednesday, April 16, 2003, at 01:26 PM, javainsel wrote:

> We want to test the creation, update and deletion of an object which
> is persisted in database.
>
> What we now do is to have three test methods for this.
>
> In the testCreate method the object is created, checked that he is
> really created and then it is deleted (we have delete because
> unfortunately we don't use Mock Objects).
>
> In the testUpdate method we create the object, update it, test the
> update result and delete the created object.
>
> In the testDelete method we create the object so that we can test
> the deletion of it.
>
> As you see, everything is included in the testUpdate method. We
> duplicate much code in the other two test methods.
>
> We write such tests for every domain object so I wonder if we should
> improve our test class.
>
> Would you write 3 or just 1 test method for that example?
>
> And would you try to convince senior coworkers who know little about
> JUnit and dislike TDD?
